thread.title: Egyptian man claims to have found missile launcher near airport
thread.title_full: Egyptian man claims to have found missile launcher near airport

title: Egyptian man claims to have found missile launcher near airport
text:
Egyptian man claims to have found missile launcher near airport By Richard Wood Shoulder-held missile launchers such as this one fired by British soldiers are a versatile and cheap weapon capable of downing low flying aircraft. 
A shoulder-launched anti-aircraft missile launcher has reportedly been found among dumped rubbish next to Cairo's main international airport. 
Egyptian man Ibrahim Yousry said he found an SA-7 missile launcher beside the road about 2km north of Cairo International Airport on his way to work, reports The Telegraph . 
Yousry wrote on Facebook that he was at first afraid to report the launcher to police in case they thought that he was a terrorist. But he said he decided it was too dangerous to leave the weapon. 
"The airport is not far away and it could cause disasters if it was placed here for a reason," he wrote. 
"The airplanes here are an easy target because they fly at very low altitude and this is the best position for this weapon to be used." An image of the missile launcher Ibrahim Yousry posted on social media. (Image: Facebook). 
The weapon did not appear to be loaded with a missile, he added. 
With a maximum range of 4km, the missile launcher could down a low-flying commercial plane landing or taking-off from the nearby airport. 
In his post, Yousry expressed alarm at finding the weapon. 
"The airplanes here are an easy target because they fly at very low altitude and this is the best position for this weapon to be used." 
Its discovery poses a headache for Western countries such as Britain which closely monitors airport security across Egypt and is weighing up whether to resume tourist flights to Sharm el-Sheikh after a Russian jet was blown up by terrorists linked to Islamic State in 2015. Wreckage of the Russian airliner downed after leaving an Egyptian tourist resort in 2015. (Photo: AFP). 
Yousry's post from Saturday quickly went viral in Egypt but he took it down fearing it would land him in trouble with the country's authoritarian government. 
Instead he replaced it with the cryptic sentence: "Fishing in troubled waters is not my style." 
Arms expert James Bevan examined photos of the launcher at the request of The Telegraph . 
Bevan, executive director of Conflict Armament Research, said it was impossible to tell if the weapon was real based on a social media photograph but that it looked like an SA-7b, a common portable anti-aircraft launcher. Â© Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017
